DeLisle Site RMP Program 3 Accidental Release Prevention Program



The Plant Manager is the top position on this site, and has responsibility for staffing the position of site Process Safety Lead (who is also the site RMP regulatory resource), and a Process Safety Committee comprised of a site leader for each of the elements of the Program 3 Prevention Program.  The Process Safety lead and the Process Safety Committee meet regularly and participate in a Corporate network of Process Safety leader s from other plants in the company to discuss best practices.  Process Safety information and internal metrics are discussed once a month by the site Process Safety lead at a meeting with the Plant Manager and site managers.  At this monthly meetings, the results of internal audits on each Program 3 component is presented at least once a year.  The purpose of these audits is to check compliance against regulatory requirements and relevant internal standards and procedures. The site Process Safety leader holds an annual review with the Plant Manager, the Process Safety Committee and other plant managers to assess the effectiveness of the Program 3 Prevention Program.



The site has identified which process segments are subject to RMP regulations, and is in compliance with the requirements of all the elements of a Process 3 Prevention Program:  40 CFR 68.65 (Process Safety Information), 68.67 (Process Hazards Analysis). 68.69 (Operating Procedures), 68.71 (Training), 68.73 (Mechanical Integrity), 68.75 (Management of Change), 68.77 (Pre-Startup Review), 68.79 (Compliance Audits), 68.81 (Incident Investigation), 68.83 (Employee Participation), 68.85 (Hot Work Permit), 68.87 (Contractors), 68.90 (Emergency Response), 68.93 (Emergency response coordination activities).



Five-Year accident history



The success of the site's RMP Prevention Program (and related activities in compliance with OSHA Process Safety Management Regulations at 29 CFR 1910.119) can be gauged by the fact that in the past five (5) years, there have been no accidental releases that resulted in OSHA recordable injuries or off-site shelter-in-place notifications or evacuations of neighbors. Site policy is to investigate all small leaks of Chlorine and Titanium Tetrachloride to continuously eliminate the root causes as an effective way of preventing the occurrence of larger leaks.  



Emergency response program 



The site is a responding site that maintains its own emergency response organization with the capacity to mitigate releases of regulated substances.  The site is in compliance with Emergency Response requirements:  68.95 (Emergency response program), 68.96 (Emergency response exercises).



The organizational structure and the lines of authority at the DeLisle Plant for PSM/RMP implementation and compliance are as follows:

Executive Summary Required by 40 CFR 68.155 



(a) Accidental Release prevention and emergency response policies



The DeLisle plant follows the Chemours Environmental, Health, Safety and Sustainability Policy (Corporate Document CP-P02) which reads:  Our purpose guides

our unshakable commitment to protect the environment and the health and safety of our customers, colleagues, and communities. As part of an ever changing world, we strive to: Drive Environmental Responsibility "We follow all environmental laws and regulations and fulfill our voluntary commitments. We are committed to

pollution prevention and actively look for ways to reduce our environmental footprint. We are committed to remediation projects and environmental initiatives that protect people and the environment. Chemours will always strive to do what's right for the environment and the communities in which we operate."



(b) The stationary source and regulated substances handled.



The Chemours Plant at DeLisle, Mississippi is located on the north shore of the Bay of St. Louis about 15 miles west of Gulfport, Mississippi.  The plant is located on a 2,417-acre site; however, only about 348 acres are developed.  The Delisle Plant manufactures a single product, Titanium Dioxide (TiO2), under the trade name TiPure(TM).  Titanium dioxide is manufactured via the chloride-ilmenite process in which naturally-occurring ilmenite (TiO2) is directly chlorinated to make Titanium Tetrachloride (TiCl4); the TiCl4 is subsequently re-oxidized to yield pure TiO2. 



The DeLisle Plant has two production lines.  Both were constructed prior to the date of applicability of OSHA PSM regulations (29 CFR 1910.119) on March 26, 1992.  Line I started operations in September, 1979 and Line 2 in March, 1991.  



EPA RMP regulations came into effect on June 21, 1999.  The Titanium Dioxide process is the only process on site.  It is subject to RMP regulations, but not to PSM regulations given that it has not been sufficien

tly modified to be considered a "new" process, and therefore, trigger PSM applicability.  



As required by 40 CFR 68.10(d)(1), the DeLisle Site has implemented a Program 3 Accidental Release Prevention Program. 



The RMP covered chemicals pursuant to 40 CFR 68.115 - Threshold, and 68.130 - List of substances, at this facility are Chlorine and Titanium Tetrachloride.  RMP applicability is limited to the following process segments at the DeLisle Plant: 1) Reaction Area (except Coke and Ore Unloading and Storage), Oxidation, Purification, and Power (Ton Cl2 containers for water treatment).  Site processes not subject to RMP applicability are:  Environmental, Power (other that Cl2 for H2O Treatment), Finishing, Slurry and Packing.  The site has documented the rationale for making this determination.  This document is Confidential Business Information, but it is available at the site upon request.
